15) This new lead guides them towards a dire prediction - the city's much-loved mayor, a primary force behind the redevelopment initiative, could possibly be the murderer's next target.
16) With time against them, the duo hurtles into motion, attempting to prevent the anticipated assassination, braving the perilous territories of the city’s criminal underworld and combative mob factions.

18) A suspense-filled showdown ensues where they manage to extricate the mayor from death's grip, saving him from the mysterious murderer held at bay.
19) Stunned and relieved crowd witnesses the unmasking of the true culprit - the city's powerful yet covertly malevolent councilmember, who was masterminding the gruesome murders all along.
20) His hidden agenda is deviously simple yet ruthlessly effective - to obstruct the redevelopment plans and maintain unchecked reign over the city's lucrative underworld and its illicit activities.
21) Despite the intense struggle and personal injuries that ensued, Jake and Alex successfully apprehend the wicked councilmember.
22) His gruesome killing spree thwarted, the rogue councilmember is handed over to the authorities, marking an end to the horrifying chain of murders.
23) Post this encounter, Jake and Alex pledge to continue their unwavering fight against the city's unending crime waves.
24) The film concludes with a promise of more thrilling adventures to come, as the duo reaffirms their sacred vow to keep the city safe.

5) Randall Lock, an overweight, alcoholic former sheriff whose daughter was tortured and killed by the duo, sees a news report that Johnny and Clyde have returned to Rhode Island, and hires bail bondsman One Time to help gain revenge.
6) Johnny and Clyde rob one of the casino's armored cars and torture a guard for information about Alana's secret cash room.
7) They use the guard as a human shield when ambushed by Lock and One Time and are able to escape when maniacal killer Zhang makes an indiscriminate attack to cause chaos.
8) To help rob the casino, Johnny assembles a team of his equally murderous foster-care brothers: suicidal thrill-seeker Butcher, insane arsonist Baker, and paranoid conspiracy theorist Candlestick.
9) Candlestick warns them that the satanic cult of the demon Bakwas performed a mass suicide at the site where the cash room was built.
10) The casino's head of security Guy suspects the serial killers, and Lock informs Alana of their intention to rob her secret cash room.
11) This provokes Alana to have the Elder of the cult perform a ritual, empowering Alana to use a mystical stone to control Bakwas and force him to guard her casino.
12) To maintain the secret of the stone, Alana then kills the Elder.
13) In preparation for the heist, Johnny's crew take an excessive amount of illegal drugs.
14) They kill the perimeter guards, then Baker accidentally kills himself while using explosive charges to open the door.
15) The crew enter the building and are quickly surrounded by Lock and One Time, who are waiting in ambush, and Zhang, who follows behind them.
16) This Mexican standoff is interrupted by Alana's announcement that the building has been locked and everyone will be dead by sunrise.
17) Bakwas appears and kills One Time.Johnny's crew descend toward the basement cash room, killing a series of guards.
18) Guy's elite team traps them but are killed by Bakwas, and Guy realizes that he has been betrayed as Alana is eliminating every possible witness.
19) Guy gives his team permission to abandon their posts.
20) It is revealed that Alana already moved all the money and is preparing to leave town and reunite with her father.
21) After Candlestick and Butcher are killed, Johnny and Clyde try to escape with a bag of counterfeit money.
22) Zhang, on orders from Alana's father, gets them out of the building.
23) Lock, who is once again waiting in ambush, kills Zhang and beats Johnny.
24) When Clyde holds Lock at gunpoint, Lock reveals that Johnny killed her father and concealed the crime.
25) Clyde shoots Lock and pistol-whips Johnny, but calls his actions romantic.
26) Bakwas confronts them and while the demon cannot leave the site, it throws its machetes at Johnny and Clyde, killing them.
27) Lock, who is wearing a bulletproof vest, recovers to gleefully view their dead bodies before Bakwas kills him.
28) Guy is the only one to escape, and confronts Alana at gunpoint, demanding the stone.
29) She gives it to him and, although she believes that she still controls Bakwas, the demon rips out her beating heart.
30) Guy offers to treat the demon with "respect and dignity", but it kills him and places the stone in its body.

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each turning point. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) In a suburban town in the Southern United States, a high school student named Krista is a member of her school's theater program.
2) In her childhood, she produced short videos with her next-door neighbor, the recently graduated Adam.
3) Adam has since started a YouTube channel to which he uploads videos of himself providing demonstrations on using various models of firearms that he owns.
4) However, his videos are receiving little attention online, and his father disapproves of his focusing on his YouTube presence rather than finding a job elsewhere.
5) Nito, a skateboarder, attends the same school as Krista.
6) One day, while idling outside the apartment where he and his apathetic guardian live, Nito meets a fellow tenant named Yoni, who invites Nito to a party that night after seeing him perform a kickflip.
7) At the party, Nito interacts with Krista, who earlier that evening had watched videos of Nito skateboarding online.
8) Later on, police officers arrive to break up the party.
9) In the commotion, a male partygoer tries to grab Krista, and Nito fights him off.
10) Krista escapes but Nito is arrested.
11) After being released from jail, Nito is picked up in a car by Yoni and Yoni's friends Lena and Jarrett.
12) Yoni, Lena, and Jarrett convince Nito to help them steal items such as Hot Pockets and perfume.
13) During school, Nito and Krista grow closer; he tries to show her how to skateboard, and she teaches him how to imitate being slapped and choked for stage purposes.
14) While working on a performance inspired by a past experience Nito had with a parakeet, he and Krista share a kiss.
15) In an effort to attract more viewers and subscribers to his YouTube channel, Adam produces a dramatized video of himself detailing an experience he claimed to have had wherein he fended off an attack by a wild warthog using a firearm.
16) When the video receives a number of negative and insulting comments, Adam becomes infuriated and records a video of himself angrily responding to and threatening the commenters.
17) Lena drives Nito, Yoni, and Jarrett to the house where her boss lives, and demands that they break in and retrieve her vape pen, which her boss confiscated from her.
18) Her boss is Adam's mother, and when Nito, Yoni, and Jarrett enter the house, Adam hears them from his upstairs bedroom.
19) Jarrett begins to ascend the stairs leading up to the house's second floor, and Adam fatally shoots him from the top of the stairs with a rifle.
20) After Adam proceeds to shoot Yoni, Nito attempts to flee, but is shot and killed by Adam after running outside.
21) Krista, walking home from school with a friend, watches Nito die and sees an armed Adam standing in the doorway to the house.
22) The incident is covered by the news, prompting Adam's YouTube channel to receive a surge of popularity.
23) Online commenters and local police officials refer to Adam as a "hero" for standing his ground against the three intruders.
24) Adam continues to make firearms-based videos that prove successful with his online followers, while Krista becomes an emotional wreck at school over the loss of Nito.
25) When Adam is invited to speak at a conference about firearms, Krista attends and follows him into a restroom to confront him.
26) She forces him to put his hands around her neck and she screams, drawing the attention of police officers in the building.
27) Adam is detained, and the video he made in which he threatens his YouTube commenters is leaked to the public.
28) Meanwhile, Krista returns to her theater classes with a sense of closure.

Story Arc Types:
- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)

Story, broken down into numbered sentences:

2) It then delves into Ross's background, portraying him as a well-educated aspiring entrepreneur living in Austin, Texas.
3) Ross comes up with the idea for Silk Road as a way to challenge government control and regulations, believing in the idea of taking back liberty.
4) He starts the website to allow anonymous buying and selling of illegal goods.
5) The movie introduces Ross Ulbricht, a charismatic and tech-savvy young man who creates the Silk Road, an underground website that facilitates the sale of illegal drugs and other contraband using cryptocurrencies.
6) Ulbricht adopts the alias "Dread Pirate Roberts" to operate the site anonymously.
7) Ross meets Julia, a student who becomes his lover and partner in crime.
8) As Silk Road gains popularity, Ross makes millions by facilitating the sale of illegal items such as drugs, weapons, and identity information.
9) However, when a Gawker article about Silk Road brings unwanted attention, law enforcement begins investigating the darknet marketplace.
10) DEA agent Rick Bowden, who has been reassigned to the cybercrimes unit after rehab, is tasked with investigating Silk Road.
11) He enlists an informant to teach him about darknet activities, leading to clashes with fellow agents and strains in his personal life.
12) As Silk Road thrives, Ross becomes increasingly isolated from Julia and his friend Max, who express concerns about his illegal activities.
13) Ross, operating under the alias Dread Pirate Roberts, becomes a sensation on Silk Road and engages in various interactions with sellers and buyers on the website, all while maintaining a sense of invincibility.
14) DEA agents, including Rick, work tirelessly to track down the owner of Silk Road, leading to a sting operation orchestrated by Rick.
15) The film portrays Ross's eventual arrest and the dismantling of Silk Road.
16) Throughout the movie, the personal struggles of both Ross and Rick are depicted, shedding light on their motivations and challenges.
17) Ross's arrest has a profound impact on his relationships and the lives of those affected by Silk Road.
18) The film touches on themes of hubris, greed, and the clash between individual freedom and law enforcement.
19) It also explores the complexities of Ross's character and the blurred lines between the moralities of the law and the actions of its enforcers.
20) As the Silk Road gains notoriety, law enforcement agencies become determined to shut it down.
21) Rick Bowden, a DEA agent, takes on the case and begins investigating Ulbricht.
22) Bowden is portrayed as a dedicated law enforcement officer who is intent on bringing down Silk Road and its elusive operator.
23) Ross Ulbricht continues to manage Silk Road, amassing a substantial fortune through the illicit marketplace.
24) He forms alliances and confronts threats from both law enforcement and rival criminals within the dark web.
25) In the end, Ross Ulbricht is arrested and faces the legal consequences of his actions, highlighting the significant impact of Silk Road on the world of online criminal enterprises and the ongoing debate about the boundaries of individual liberty and government intervention in the digital age.
26) The film reaches its climax when Ulbricht is finally apprehended by law enforcement, and his true identity is revealed.
27) He is arrested and faces a lengthy trial for drug trafficking, money laundering, and other charges related to Silk Road.
28) During the trial, Ulbricht's defense team argues that he was framed and that he is not the true Dread Pirate Roberts.

Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) In Boston, Clancy Finch is invited by her crush Travis Schultz to a party at his house.
2) Her brother Kevin is caught dancing in the restroom by some older students who record him and bully him, but Clancy's and Kevin's mother Margot, the lunch monitor, scares them away.
3) The bullies upload a remix video of Kevin dancing and Margot admonishing them to YouTube, where it quickly goes viral, gaining over two million views.
4) Kevin, Clancy, and her friend Mim are picked up by their father Ron, an awkward pastry chef.
5) Clancy asks her parents if she can go to Travis's party and they both say no, leading to her insulting her mother and getting grounded.
6) Later, Kevin's friend Lewis comes over for a sleepover in a tent in the backyard.
7) That night, Clancy and Mim sneak out.
8) On their way to the party, they first scare the boys, causing Lewis to run into the house to pee.
9) While in the bathroom, he notices a man and a woman break into the house, force Ron at gun point and Margot (whom they call "Matilda") to come with them under threat of Ron's death to get their group back together.
10) Margot agrees, removing her necklace as a clueless Ron is brought along.
11) Lewis runs back to the tent and tells the others what happened.
12) Not believing him, the four run back inside until they notice United States Marshals Agent Henry Gibbs sneaking into the house.
13) An intruder, they attack him, tying him to a chair.
14) He tells them Margot was in the Witness Protection Program because she turned in the boss of the crime syndicate she was in, but has been located due to the viral video.
15) In another location, Elise and her associate are briefed on the mission.
16) Also present is Margot's criminal ex-fiancé Leo Bouchot, who had been in the Witness Protection Program before he was found.
17) The kids follow clues Margot left them in the flour and her necklace when she was taken away, leading them to a storage unit, a secret spy center.
18) They take a self-driving spy car to Travis's party.
19) Travis agrees to take them to Downtown Boston in his family's boat, but they are stopped by the U.S. Coast Guard and he has a revoked license.
20) The four jump off and swim away, then reach the building where they believe their parents are located.
21) They instead find a secret passageway behind a painting of Margot's favorite poet W. B. Yeats leading them to the hideout of Margot's best friend Jay, who tracks Margot's GPS chip to an extravagant gala.
22) Jay tells them to stay, but Clancy handcuffs her to a pipe so they can all leave.
23) At the gala, Ron, Margot, and Leo plan to steal Queen of Moldana's crown by giving her a non-lethal poison.
24) Upon meeting her, Ron accidentally ingests the poison and vomits everywhere, so gala security detains them.
25) When they are about to be sent to the FBI, Margot and Leo knock out all the security guards.
26) They go with Ron to the main floor, where they find the four kids, who got in by pretending to be live musicians.
27) The seven escape to Leo's safe house.
28) There, they discover Leo was never in the Witness Protection Program, but is actually the new head of the syndicate.
29) Elise holds them at gunpoint and calls the police, framing them for the theft.
30) Ron throws a wolf spider at her so she drops her gun and then shoots the chandelier so it subdues her.
31) Margot hot-wires a car that Ron uses to drive Leo into a bunch of construction barrels, then Margot kicks the crown out of his hands and Clancy catches it.
32) The Boston Police arrest Leo and those involved.
33) Henry drives everyone back to the Finch house where Travis returns Clancy's jacket and Lewis's mother picks him up.
34) Everyone returns to their normal lives.

13) His academic life takes a riveting turn as he takes up an actual murder case and investigates it parallelly with his book writing endeavor.

1) In the year 43,000, B.C., a starving, ragtag group of six prehistoric humans has reached the shores of a new world searching for food and a new place to live.
2) Adem is the leader of the group and has been joined by his pregnant mate, Ave, his younger brother, Geirr, and his 11-year-old son, Heron.
3) Also with them are Beyah, a young female 'stray' with a low ranking in the group, and Odal, an elder who was allowed to accompany the group because of his wisdom.
4) Heron asks Beyah for a story, but after her refusal, Odal relates how the boy's father has taken them on an adventure based on childhood stories in order to find a new life.
5) As they journey towards the mountains to find a new cave, the group is ambushed in the night by a mysterious creature, and Heron is abducted.
6) The group wait until morning to track the creature and the young boy, and are forced to follow Adem when he insists on pursuing the creature into the woods where the trail leads.
7) The group becomes lost in the forest, and as darkness falls, Adem hears mysterious noises in the wood and runs in pursuit while the others hold back.
8) Adem is attacked, and is brought back to the group's camp by Geirr with mortal wounds.
9) Geirr is unable to put Adem out of his misery, so Beyah steps forwards to end his suffering and then suggests the group cannibalize the body to avoid starving.
10) Geirr is unable to consume his brother’s flesh and buries it in the ground, but the others in the group partake.
11) Geirr, now assuming leadership of the group, attempts to lead the group through the woods and toward the mountain where he hopes that they will find a cave, but only manages to lead them in circles.
12) Odal, believing that they are being stalked by a demon, blames the catastrophe on Beyah and attempts to sacrifice her to it with Ave and Geirr, but she escapes, knocking out Geirr in the process.
13) Odal, in turn, offers a replacement sacrifice to the demon by stabbing Ave with a tree branch, but she breaks his ankle with her last breath.
14) During a night of aurora borealis, a crippled Odal watches as the creature takes Ave's body.
15) The following dawn, Beyah finds Geirr and they decide to go towards the mountain.
16) They then witness the creature killing Odal and ambush it, only to discover it is a female Neanderthal wearing a mask.
17) They trail her to the mountain and find a cave, where Beyah believes the Neanderthal has taken shelter.
18) As Beyah enters the cave, she is attacked by a male Neanderthal and nearly killed.
19) She feigns death, but then attacks and mortally wounds the man.
20) She continues into the cave where she discovers an unharmed Heron in a bed of furs, whereupon she is confronted by the Neanderthal female wielding a rock hammer.
21) In the meantime, Geirr, hearing Beyah's scream, tries to follow her and comes across where the male Neanderthal lays dying.
22) He finishes him off with his spear and continues through the cave to find Beyah, finally reaching her at the cave, whereupon the female Neanderthal attacks Geirr and kills him.
23) The female then threatens Beyah, who promptly sets the furs on fire and escapes with Heron through a small opening in the cave that serves as a chimney.
24) As the female Neanderthal attempts to escape through the hole, Heron tries to help her, but Beyah instead smashes her head in with a rock.
25) She tells Heron the Neanderthals are monsters who killed his father, while he says they abducted him in order to feed and protect him, knowing he would starve if he remained with the group.
26) The film ends with Beyah's story to Heron, detailing her regret of killing the Neanderthals, and remarking that they were just fearful human beings, as terrified of the unknown as Beyah and her group were.
27) Heron shows Beyah Ave’s body laid out in honor, covered in ritual paint and funeral clothing as prepared by the Neanderthals.
28) The two proceed to bury Ave, Geirr and the two Neanderthals.
29) Beyah, now claiming the Neanderthals’ cave as her and Heron's own, remarks that they will be the first of a new people, and that they will try again to survive with the lessons that they have learned.

Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Cherie is a young single mother and pre-law student working as a secretary for a legal firm in Los Angeles.
2) On her way home, her boss James calls her saying that she double-booked him for dinner with an important client at the same time as his anniversary dinner, which Cherie has no memory of.
3) James asks Cherie to go to the dinner for him and she reluctantly accepts.
4) While preparing for the dinner, Cherie's period starts and she realizes that she is out of tampons.
5) Cherie meets the client, Ethan, at his house and the two go to dinner.
6) Cherie is charmed by Ethan, although he has a sudden outburst of anger when approached by a dog, explaining that he was bitten by one as a child.
7) Ethan invites Cherie to spend the night with him, setting an alarm on his phone for the early morning so that she can return home before her daughter wakes up.
8) When he does, Cherie notices that he already has an alarm for 5:25 AM.
9) She agrees to stay for a drink.
10) When they enter his house, Ethan attacks Cherie, causing her to flee.
11) Running down the street, Cherie tries to get help from nearby residents but is ignored.
12) She finally finds two women outside a movie theater and convinces them to call 911.
13) The police arrive and arrest Cherie for public intoxication, despite her protestations that she was attacked.
14) Cherie talks to another woman in the cell who panics when Cherie describes Ethan.
15) The woman warns Cherie that Ethan "controls men" and urges her to seek the "First Lady".
16) The police escort Ethan into Cherie's cell, where he tells her that he will hunt her, and that if she survives until morning, he will let her go.
17) Upon being released, Cherie heads to James' apartment.
18) He seems sympathetic, offering her clean clothes to wear.
19) Cherie searches for information about Ethan on James' computer and finds that she is the latest in a long string of women marked as tithes for Ethan.
20) James' wife, Judy, warns Cherie that Ethan can smell her blood and that she should clean herself thoroughly.
21) Cherie flees on a bus and then calls her ex-boyfriend Trey for help.
22) While stopping at a gas station to buy tampons, Cherie is ambushed by Ethan.
23) She strikes him in the head and escapes with the help of Trey, who drives her to his place, despite the fact that his new girlfriend Dawn, Cherie's former best friend, is there.
24) Realizing that Cherie has been attacked, Dawn is unexpectedly sympathetic.
25) When Ethan arrives looking for Cherie, Dawn and her friends arm themselves to fight him off, but he easily kills them.
26) Ethan forces Cherie to leave with him.
27) Trey, who had gone out, returns home and confronts Ethan, who decapitates him.
28) Cherie flees, and remembering Judy's advice, throws some of her menstrual blood onto a passing car to mislead Ethan.
29) Cherie flees to a church where she asks the priest for holy water and a crucifix, hoping to ward off Ethan.
30) She discovers the body of the priest and realizes that Ethan had assumed his form.
31) Ethan then reveals his true form to Cherie.
32) Returning to human form, Ethan is attacked by the priest, allowing Cherie to escape.
33) Cherie finds her way into an underground rave, where she sees a flyer for the First Lady and calls the number on it, getting the location for a nearby spa.
34) When Cherie is accosted by a man, she is rescued by a group of party girls who take her with them.
35) As they leave the rave, the girls offer to take Cherie surfing in the early morning, but Cherie realizes that Ethan's alarm was set for sunrise.
36) Just then, Ethan attacks them until Cherie is saved when a pitbull shows up, barking at Ethan and causing him to disappear.
37) At the spa, Cherie discovers the "First Lady", Dinah, and a group of women practicing martial arts.
38) Dinah explains that Ethan is a fallen angel whose job was to protect and guide humanity.
39) Ethan had decided that men should rule and used his prodigious powers to assure masculine ascendance throughout history.
40) Dinah says that she needs to use Cherie as bait to lure Ethan out so that he can be defeated.
41) The women clean Cherie up and she drives to the Santa Monica Pier.
42) There, Cherie reopens her wounds, attracting Ethan.
43) As Ethan prepares to kill Cherie, his alarm rings and he realizes that the dawn has arrived.
44) Cherie throws a rock through a blacked-out window, exposing Ethan to the sunlight and incapacitating him.
45) The women from the spa, who have gathered outside, throw more rocks through the windows, flooding the room with sunlight and mortally weakening Ethan.
46) Outside, Cherie mocks the now-weakened Ethan as his power dies.
47) Dinah lights Ethan on fire, killing him.
48) Cherie then returns home to her daughter.

Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) In the stunning opening frame, the movie immerses us into an intense murder scene within a lavishly decorated seventieth-story penthouse bathed in a sublime golden glow, nestled in the throbbing heart of Sin city, Las Vegas.
2) The gruesome murder victim is revealed as Jackson Kline, a prominent business magnate recognized as a pivotal piston in the city's clandestine and unsavory underworld.
3) Ray Chandler, highly decorated investigative journalist for the prestigious Las Vegas Tribune known for his tenacious pursuit of truth, is hand-picked by his hard-nosed editor, Ed Williams, to uncover the layers surrounding this brewing scandal.
4) His relentless pursuit leads him to the glimmering grand halls of the notorious Quad Stallion Gambling Club, a temptation-filled oasis nestled amidst Vegas's towering casinos.
5) When Ray dares to penetrate the stronghold of the club's guarded entrance, he faces the blunt refusal of burly, intimidating guards lacquered in black suits like menacing ravens.
6) However, amidst this display of power, his presence piques the attention of Serena, the enigmatic and tantalizingly captivating brunette owner of the club who is as mysterious as she is beautiful.
7) As he interacts with Serena, he stumbles upon cryptic murmurs about "Rumors", an elusive entity holding extensive power in the shady underworld.
8) As he succumbs to Serena's intoxicating allure, he unearths salacious secrets whispered in hushed tones amidst the city's extravagant, champagne-drenched parties.
9) But what takes him by surprise is the magnitude of these secrets, revealing shocking connections that extend beyond Jackson Kline's cold-blooded murder.
10) Serena, gradually lowering her guard, invites Ray deeper into her clandestine realm, unraveling the dangerous allure of the forbidden underworld in front of his curious eyes.
11) As they venture further into ambiguity, their relationship transcends from a tense cat and mouse game to becoming unlikely partners in an escalating battle for power and survival.
12) Ray gets tangled in a web of conflicting emotions, torn between his blossoming affection for the sultry Serena and his devout pursuit for justice unmoved by personal connections.
13) Behind the dazzling glamour of Vegas, Ray and Serena traverse the treacherous labyrinth of deception and lies deeply entrenched in the city's shadowy underbelly.
14) As they unwind the complex mystery surrounding the elusive 'Rumors', they expose a sprawling network of corruption involving the city's untouchable elite.
15) However, this revelation is not without its price, they find themselves in the hazardous crosshairs of imminent peril.
16) Barely escaping death in an ambush staged in a dim-lit, grimy back alley by faceless assassins, they manage to dodge a hurtling storm of deadly bullets.
17) The near-death encounter jolts Serena into unraveling her tightly held underworld connections in front of Ray, extending a trusting hand in uncertain times.
18) Driven by a mutual desire for retribution, together, they strategize a daring plan to unmask the elusive and seemingly untouchable Rumors, vowing to cut down the rotten tree of organized crime infecting their world.
19) As they delve deeper into the dark maze of deception, they get entangled in a monstrous web of manipulation and power games spread across the city, far more sprawling than what they initially suspected.
20) Armed to the hilt with their risky discoveries, they decide to face Rumors head-on in the smoke-infused, lavishly adorned halls of high-stakes casinos and opulent penthouses, willingly putting their lives on the line.
21) The nail-biting climax lays bare ill-kept loyalties and stunning betrayals, the revelation adding kindling to the already blazing inferno searing its way through the narrative.
22) After a nerve-wracking chase through Vegas's sprawling cityscape, Ray and Serena manage to corner Rumors, who appears visibly taken aback by their united front.
23) With one decisive roll of a dice, a metaphor shining bright in a city perpetually under the glow of neon lights, Ray succeeds in unmasking Rumors, sparking off an unprecedented chain reaction in Vegas's crime hierarchy.
24) Capitalizing on the disarray sparked within rival gangs, he publishes a hard-hitting expose in the Las Vegas Tribune, sending tremors across the world of notoriety, causing several crime syndicates to crumble overnight, including Serena's Quad Stallion Gambling Club.
25) Consumed by the aftermath of Ray's daring expose, Serena starts detaching herself from her underworld shadows, looking for paths leading towards redemption from a world she once controlled.
26) Having cemented his legacy in investigative journalism with another landmark story, Ray decides to pursue fresher leads possibly leading to another explosive expose, leaving Serena behind.
27) The repercussions of the expose are far-reaching, with court cases popping up across the city, unearthing long buried secrets, and forever altering the landscape of Las Vegas.
28) The taste of victory for Ray is an odd blend of sweet and sour.
29) His heart aches with unspoken feelings for Serena, standing as a permanent reminder of the personal sacrifices necessary to unveil the harsh truth.
30) Meanwhile, Serena watches as Ray's departing figure blends into the desert horizon, her heart heavy with the weight of a world drastically different from the one she was previously part of.
31) Despite the unexpected downfall of her once glittering empire, Serena embarks on a long journey to redemption, aiming to transition from a feared queen of sin to an ordinary citizen seeking forgiveness.
32) In a different world altogether, Ray is seen hunched over countless case notes in a dim-lit bar in a quiet town, well on his way to unravel another mystery miles away from the glitz and grime of Las Vegas.
33) Leaving behind her notorious status, Serena now roams around the halls of her once thriving casino, the echoes of the past bouncing off its sinister silence.
34) For Ray, the successful expose rings the closing bell on the infamous Las Vegas underworld, while simultaneously opening doors to yet another hard-hitting expose.
35) The camera zooms out to catch Serena's wistful gaze tune to Ray's dwindling silhouette, her heart burdened with a fresh start and yet pulsating with newfound resolution.
36) The movie reaches its thrilling apex, freezing Serena in contemplation of her next move, leaving viewers at the edge of their seats, their anticipation heightened as the end credits begin to roll.

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each turning point. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Renowned for his heroism on the Apollo-50 mission, Richard Patterson, a seasoned astronaut, assumes a powerful leadership position within NASA's vibrant and bustling command center.
2) His years of experience and wisdom fall upon a diverse team—each member carrying an essential piece of the puzzle in pioneering humanity's leap into space.
3) Alongside Richard, Margaret "Meg" Smith, a gifted space engineer whose genius rivals that of the creators of the Hubble telescope, serves as a steady voice of reason and logic—an intellectual powerhouse in the team.
4) Joining this elite team with a heart pounding with nerves and excitement, Jack Philips steps into the world of “Orbital Engineers”—an adept group of repair and maintenance maestros navigating the void of outer space.
5) Richard and Meg, often seen swapping playful banter and classic jibes, not only showcase a camaraderie that was formed decades ago during their first NASA training but also a deep-seated respect and understanding for each other—admirable pillars of their enduring friendship.
6) Jack, fueled by an ambition that could even compete with the pioneering Wright brothers, puts everything on the line.
7) He spends countless hours honing his orbital maneuvering and emergency repair skills, determined to master every complexity and nuance of this art.
8) Their mission—to repair the Hubble Space Telescope that is playing havoc with astronomical tracking on Earth— set forth a daring ascent into the void of space aboard the technologically advanced SpaceX Dragon spacecraft.
9) As they near the iconic Hubble, tension blankets the cabin.
10) The team diligently prepares for their endeavor, equipping themselves with their Extravehicular Mobility Units (EMUs) and unfurling their toolkit against the backdrop of cold, unwavering stars.
11) During his maiden spacewalk, Jack meticulously documents each of his actions on the spacecraft’s state-of-the-art onboard computer system before taking on the critical task of maintenance on the Hubble.
12) However, what started as an ordinary expedition pivots towards disaster when, hidden within the complex workings of the Hubble, they unearth a time bomb threatening devastation on an unprecedented scale.
13) Fear, painted across Jack's green eyes, is echoed amongst the crew.
14) Still, Richard and Meg composure remains unwavering, a testament to their years of rigorous astronautical training and emotional resilience.
15) With the ticking bomb as their ominous companion, Meg and Jack throw themselves into work.
16) The weight of humanity's survival lies heavy on their shoulders, entrusted to their space-suited forms.
17) The situation spirals when the dormant bomb triggers a slew of anomalies in the linked GPS satellites, compounding challenges on Earth.
18) Amid a barrage of stray satellites set loose by the bomb’s detonation, Richard sustains a crippling injury that incapacitates him—leaving the less-experienced Meg and Jack adrift in a sea of mounting challenges.
19) Out of necessity, Meg and Jack find themselves shouldering the relentless tasks of satellite salvage operations and the urgent disarmament of the deadly bomb.
20) Despite his agonizing injury, Richard calls upon every shred of willpower to guide Meg and Jack, fueling them with much-needed practical wisdom and advice through the agony that threatens to engulf him.
21) Demonstrating exceptional courage and determination, Meg and Jack formulate a daring strategy to halt the countdown of the bomb while simultaneously combating the satellite anomalies.
22) With the clock mercilessly ticking away and leaving them a paltry hour to achieve their goals, they dive into their plan—hands steady, movements precise, and minds fixated on the monumental task despite the stress escalator.
23) The frantic voices from Houston’s Mission Control are drowned in the sea of time constraints, leaving the astronauts to rely solely on their instincts, experience, and the fruits of their intensive training.
24) Pitted against astronomical odds and guided by Richard’s vital advice, Meg and Jack push aside their fears and throw themselves into a race against time, leaving no room for error.
25) In the face of impending disaster, with merely seconds on the countdown clock, they manage to disarm the bomb and rectify the malfunctioning satellites—pulling Earth from the jaws of catastrophe.
26) However, the fiasco takes a tragic turn when Richard's life is swiftly teetering on the edge due to his grievous injuries.
27) Despite their desperate efforts and hopeful prayers, Richard succumbs to his wounds.
28) His final moments blossom in the deafening silence aboard the spacecraft, his last act symbolizing a hero's sacrifice for humanity, mirrored in the last flicker of his life.
29) Back on Earth, Mission Control and the world erupt into euphoria as the systems revert to normal, narrowly averting the disaster that had held its breath to strike.
30) Returning to Earth as celebrated heroes, Meg and Jack, enshrouded in exhaustion, wear their victory as a mantle— their faces glowing through the weariness, the testament of an adventure that was as harrowing as it was triumphant.
31) Richard's brave deed joins the annals of space history, his heroic saga destined to inspire future generations toward astronomical aspirations.
32) Having undergone a profound metamorphosis amid a crisis, Jack steps into Richard's enormous shoes, carrying forward his legacy and teachings for future missions.
33) As the story concludes on a heartrending note, Richard's sacrifice carves a path of honor in the annals of space history—providing a stepping stone for Jack, who strides forward to helm future missions, with the ever-dependable Meg always at his side.
34) The history of space exploration carries forth, enriched by sacrifice, culminating in hope for humanity's cosmic journey.

Story Arc Types:
- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)

Ground Truth Turning Points:
- Opportunity (tp1): 4.0 - Introductory event that occurs after presenting the setting and background of the main characters.
- Change of Plans (tp2): 8.0 - Event where the main goal of the story is defined, starting the main action.
- Point of No Return (tp3): 15.0 - Event that pushes the main character(s) to fully commit to their goal.
- Major Setback (tp4): 25.0 - Event where things fall apart temporarily or permanently.
- Climax (tp5): 33.0 - Final event/resolution of the main story (the "biggest spoiler").

The protagonist in the story is Jack Philips, as the narrative focuses on his journey, growth, and challenges throughout the mission.

### 2. At the sentence indicated by the first turning point, state the sentence again, and describe the protagonist's state.
The first turning point (Opportunity) is at sentence 4.0: "Joining this elite team with a heart pounding with nerves and excitement, Jack Philips steps into the world of “Orbital Engineers”—an adept group of repair and maintenance maestros navigating the void of outer space."
At this point, Jack is nervous and excited, indicating a mix of emotions but overall, he is in a state of anticipation and eagerness to prove himself. His condition can be approximated as a 6, considering he is about to embark on a significant challenge but has the support of an experienced team.

### 3. Identify the second turning point and state the sentence corresponding to that turning point, and describe how it changed relative to the first turning point.

Relative to the first turning point, Jack's condition has become more focused and determined as he now has a clear mission objective. His condition can be approximated as a 7, indicating a slight improvement as he is now engaged in a meaningful task.

### 4. Identify the third turning point and state the sentence corresponding to that turning point, and describe how it changed relative to the second turning point.
The third turning point (Point of No Return) is at sentence 15.0: "With the ticking bomb as their ominous companion, Meg and Jack throw themselves into work."
Compared to the second turning point, Jack's situation has become more dire due to the discovery of the bomb, indicating a significant challenge. However, his determination and commitment to finding a solution have increased. His condition can be approximated as a 4, showing a decline due to the increased danger and responsibility.

### 5. Identify the fourth turning point and state the sentence corresponding to that turning point, and describe how it changed relative to the third turning point.
The fourth turning point (Major Setback) is at sentence 25.0: "In the face of impending disaster, with merely seconds on the countdown clock, they manage to disarm the bomb and rectify the malfunctioning satellites—pulling Earth from the jaws of catastrophe."
Relative to the third turning point, Jack and his team have successfully overcome a critical challenge by disarming the bomb, which represents a significant improvement in their situation. His condition can be approximated as an 8, indicating a notable recovery from the previous dire situation.

### 6. Identify the fifth turning point and state the sentence corresponding to that turning point, and describe how it changed relative to the fourth turning point.
The fifth turning point (Climax) is at sentence 33.0: "As the story concludes on a heartrending note, Richard's sacrifice carves a path of honor in the annals of space history—providing a stepping stone for Jack, who strides forward to helm future missions, with the ever-dependable Meg always at his side."
Compared to the fourth turning point, while Jack has achieved a victory, he has also experienced a personal loss with Richard's death. However, he is now in a position of leadership and has grown significantly. His condition can be approximated as a 9, showing an overall improvement as he has emerged stronger and more capable, despite the tragedy.

### 7. List the protagonist's condition at each turning point
The list of Jack's condition at each turning point, in chronological order, is: 6, 7, 4, 8, 9.

### 8. Classify the story arc type based on the protagonist's condition list and explain your reasoning.
The story arc type can be classified as "Double Man in a Hole" because Jack's condition initially improves (from 6 to 7), then significantly worsens (down to 4) as he faces a major challenge, followed by a recovery and improvement (up to 8 and then 9) as he overcomes these challenges and grows. This pattern reflects the "Double Man in a Hole" arc, where the protagonist faces two cycles of dilemma and recovery, ultimately ending in a better state than at the beginning.

### 9. Determined story arc type
Double Man in a Hole

Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Picking up shortly after the previous film, Rose leads the human fleet against the aliens.
2) Now called 'Harvesters', the aliens are on board the Armada, a mother ship in orbit of the Moon.
3) After breaking through the enemy lines, Rose freezes before she can fire and one of her ships is destroyed.
4) With the aliens preparing to fire on Earth, Rose is forced to destroy one of her own ships when it gets into the crossfire.
5) She sacrifices thousands of humans, but succeeds in destroying the Armada.
6) Wracked with guilt, Rose vanishes while humanity rebuilds, living alongside billions of 'Pilots', freed alien-human hybrids.
7) Five years after the battle, Rose lives in a tent city near the ruins of London, avoiding resistance forces searching for her and keeping the aging effects of her hybrid nature at bay with the help of hyper-oxygenated blood transfusions prepared by her friend Dr. Mal.
8) A viral pandemic strikes the Pilots and anyone using transplanted Pilot limbs.
9) The virus eats the Pilots alive while reverting them back into their brainwashed state.
10) Resistance leader Leon captures Rose and brings her before General Radford who reveals that the Armada's core drive warped to Cobalt One, the Harvester homeworld, before the ship's destruction.
11) Only with the Armada's core drive do they have a chance of saving the Pilots.
12) Rose reluctantly agrees to join the mission.
13) At Cobalt One, the team's ship crashes after a collision that leaves it running on emergency power.
14) The crew of Rose, her Pilot adoptive brother Trent, Leon, Owens and Alexi find the planet filled with the bodies of dead Harvesters.
15) There are also strange shadow creatures that appear to be mutations of the Harvesters.
16) Alexi is heavily wounded and sacrifices herself with a pulse grenade to kill them.
17) The team manages to reach the Armada where Rose is briefly possessed by the Harvester Matriarch, who accuses the humans of coming to destroy her species.
18) Trent helps Rose to break free of the Matriarch's control and Rose realizes that the alien's telepathic influence was what caused her to freeze in the war.
19) Now no longer afraid of who she is, Rose embraces her powers and steals the core drive.
20) However, Owens betrays the others, infects Trent with the virus and flees with the core drive.
21) Rose and Leon later discover that Radford bombed Cobalt One prior to their arrival with a biological weapon, the same virus that is infecting the Pilots on Earth.
22) As the two make their way back aboard the ship, Radford uses the core drive to destroy Cobalt One and the Harvesters in an act of genocide.
23) He reveals to them that the virus was intended to peacefully euthanize the Pilots and destroy the Harvesters, but it had the unintended side effect of reverting the Pilots back into their brainwashed state.
24) Having boarded the ship as well, the Matriarch kills Radford, intending to destroy the Earth in revenge.
25) After realizing the truth about the virus, Owens attacks Zhi, who manages to fight him off.
26) As the ship enters a wormhole, Owens falls into an energy field and is disintegrated.
27) Trent, whom Leon manages to snap back to normal, knocks the Matriarch in as well, but has most of his body disintegrated in the process.
28) On Earth, Mal works on a cure, but the infected Pilots attack before she can finish testing it.
29) The residents, including Mal, Kate, Grant and Huana, fight back and manage to eliminate the attacking Pilots at the cost of Grant and several others, only to have an army of thousands more approach from London.
30) Arriving back just in the nick of time, Rose sucks all of the Pilots into her ship.
31) With Mal's cure and her ship, they now have the power to cure all of the infected Pilots worldwide.
32) In the aftermath, Mal transplants Trent's brain into a new Pilot body, saving him.
33) Zhi hacks into Radford's personal files and discovers the location of a prison where Radford had held anyone that he considered to be an enemy of the state, including Rose and Trent's long-missing father Mark Corley.
34) Rose orders a course set for the prison, intending to rescue her adoptive father.

- Point of No Return (tp3): 19.0 - Event that pushes the main character(s) to fully commit to their goal.

The protagonist of the story is Rose.

### 2. At the sentence indicated by the first turning point, state the sentence again, and describe the protagonist's state.
The first turning point is at sentence 6: "Wracked with guilt, Rose vanishes while humanity rebuilds, living alongside billions of 'Pilots', freed alien-human hybrids." 
At this point, Rose is feeling guilty and has vanished, indicating a low point in her life. She is struggling with the consequences of her actions and is not actively engaging with the world. Her condition can be approximated as 2 out of 10.

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each turning point. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Jane, a quiet individual, lived in peaceful solitude on the secluded island of Thorne with her playful and loyal Golden Retriever, Dash.
2) Their quaint home was a small, but cozy cabin, stocked with the bare necessities—some canned food, firewood and occasional luxuries like Jane’s favorite tea.
3) However, their supplies had begun to dwindle down, threatening Jane's generally serene island existence.
4) As much as she actually wanted to resist it, Jane realized that avoiding other humans completely hadn’t become an option anymore.
5) Gathering her courage, she made the decision to sail into Silverint, the closest coastal town, to stock up on her rapidly depleting essentials.
6) Silverint was a small coastal town known for its eccentric, yet amicable inhabitants.
7) As soon as Jane disembarked from her boat, she was met with interested smiles from passers-by and curious glances from townsfolk.
8) They had not seen the elusive 'island woman' in some time.
9) Among these townsfolk was a once successful sailor turned self-proclaimed treasure hunter, Grisly.
10) A large man with a keen eye for the peculiar, he approached Jane with an offering - a brass locket, charming but undeniably aged, tarnished from years of existence.
11) Grisly insisted, with an earnest look in his eyes, that this locket was not the average trinket.
12) He claimed it held unusual power and was a relic of a forgotten era, but he remained suspiciously quiet about any more specificities.
13) Intrigued by Grisly’s cryptic assertion, Jane managed to make her way back to her island home bearing a heavy load of new supplies, crucial resources, and an undeniable curiosity to decipher the locket’s unusual essence.
14) As Jane opened the locket in the seclusion of her home, life on the tranquil island began to drastically transform backward.
15) Her serene life disrupted shockingly with a series of inexplicable events.
16) Dash, who was usually the epitome of joyful companionship, became inexplicably anxious.
17) His happy-eyed, wagging tail demeanor dissolved into constant whimpering.
18) He seemed to shy away from the vicinity of the locket and at times even Jane herself.
19) Disturbing incidents began infringing upon her peaceful homestead.
20) Freezing gusts of wind whistled within her otherwise airtight cabin, and the once calming silence of the nights vibrated with grating, untraceable noises.
21) One day, desperate and overwhelmed by the continual paranormal implications, Jane took the locket and launched it into the unending horizon of the crashing sea waves.
22) She felt an immediate sense of relief and hoped it would stay that way.
23) However, the very next morning she was chilled to find the locket perched ominously on her wooden bedside table, resistant to the maritime journey she had subjected it to.
24) Her days felt longer, and her nights were frighteningly intense, with chilling apparitions that sent icy shivers down her spine.
25) Even her inanimate cabin sprang to life, the furniture sliding around as if possessed and fleeting, sinister shadows haunting her at the corners of her eyes.
26) Terrified at the escalating ghostly predicaments, Jane decided she needed answers.
27) As the sun rose, she hopped onto her trusty sea vessel, and with a newfound determination, she faced the ocean’s wrath to get back to Silverint and corner Grisly about the truth.
28) Back in Silverint, Grisly greeted Jane with a haunted look.
29) He finally disclosed a chilling legend about the locket; supposedly, it was an enchanted prison for a powerful and ill-tempered witch, captured by a wise shaman centuries before their time.
30) Soon, whispers of Jane's encounter with the paranormal spread like wildfire around Silverint, their amicable townsfolk now treating her more skeptically, as if she were a magnet for unnatural energies.
31) Jane found herself being treated differently.
32) The food from the local diner had a strange, sour taste, and even Dash resorted to snarling every time she made an attempt to pet him.
33) Distressed, lonely, and feeling the isolation more than ever, Jane yet refused to give in to the malevolent entity.
34) Drawing upon her final reserves of energy, she fortified her resolve and swore to reclaim her peaceful life from the manifestations.
35) Bearing her ordeal, Jane turned to Father Patrick, the town's well-respected priest and spiritual guide.
36) She also sought help from Octavia, an elderly woman revered for her knowledge of historical lore and antiques, hoping to find a solution.
37) They revealed to Jane an ancient local legend, a popular but largely untested folk tale about a mythical vault hidden deep within the heart of Thorne island.
38) Folklore suggested that this vault contained magic powerful enough to reverse Jane’s chilling encounters.
39) Octavia, glancing ominously at Jane, shared a puzzling clue: the vault would only make itself visible during the rare event of a lunar eclipse.
40) This, she divulged, was to occur just the following night.
41) High on nerves, Jane began her intense preparations as per the detailed rituals from Silverint's lore.
42) She read ancient texts, memorized enchantments and mentally rehearsed the sacred rites necessary to combat the unseen enemy.
43) Sensing her resolve, the vindictive spirit took a terrifying step.
44) The peaceful tranquility of Jane's house ruptured into flames.
45) Once a serene solace, her home now seemed to be a war zone, engulfed in an inferno and trying to consume her.
46) Jane barely managed to escape the inferno, risked her life and dashed out into the darkness, only escaping with minor burns and a relentless spirit, fueled further by the desperate countermeasures the entity took.
47) On the night of the lunar eclipse, armed with nothing but her courage and a series of chants, Jane set off into the eerie wilderness of Thorne, braving supernatural obstacles set by the vengeful spirit, towards the unseen vault.
48) As she confronted the ghastly apparition, adrenaline coursing wildly through her veins, the only weapon she found she possessed was her  unwavering courage, resolute determination, and the disappearance of her previous reservations.
49) With her relentless will, she fought and triumphed, successfully trapping the malevolent entity, trapping it back into the confines of the lustrous brass locket.
50) She lodged the now dormant locket into an ancient stone niche within the concealed vault and sealed it shut, just as the last fragment of the lunar eclipse dissipated into the ebony sky.
51) Life gradually began to find its way back to Jane.
52) The town's folks' previously wary outlooks softened, Dash’s playful spirit resurfaced, and Jane began to see a glimmer of her old, tranquil life.
53) Jane’s lifestyle morphed significantly in the succeeding days.
54) She began to frequent Silverint more often and started to build forts of friendship with the once estranged townsfolk.
55) Jane had gone from the reclusive 'island woman' to becoming a symbol of resilience, a beacon of courage and a testament to determination for the entire town.
56) In conclusion, Jane is seen calmly watching the sun rise from her fixed up cabin porch, the sense of fulfillment and empowerment radiating from her was infectious, giving the audience a final sense of satisfaction after her considerable journey.

- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)

Ground Truth Turning Points:
- Opportunity (tp1): 5.0 - Introductory event that occurs after presenting the setting and background of the main characters.
- Change of Plans (tp2): 10.0 - Event where the main goal of the story is defined, starting the main action.
- Point of No Return (tp3): 14.0 - Event that pushes the main character(s) to fully commit to their goal.
- Major Setback (tp4): 29.0 - Event where things fall apart temporarily or permanently.
- Climax (tp5): 49.0 - Final event/resolution of the main story (the "biggest spoiler").

### 1. Identify the protagonist in the story
The protagonist in the story is Jane, a quiet individual living on the secluded island of Thorne with her Golden Retriever, Dash.

### 2. At the sentence indicated by the first turning point, state the sentence again, and describe the protagonist's state.
The first turning point (tp1) is at sentence 5: "Gathering her courage, she made the decision to sail into Silverint, the closest coastal town, to stock up on her rapidly depleting essentials."
At this point, Jane's state is one of necessity and mild desperation due to her dwindling supplies, but she is taking proactive steps to address her situation. Her condition can be approximated as a 5 out of 10, as she is facing challenges but is also showing resilience and determination.

### 3. Identify the second turning point and state the sentence corresponding to that turning point, and describe how it changed relative to the first turning point.
The second turning point (tp2) is at sentence 10: "A large man with a keen eye for the peculiar, he approached Jane with an offering - a brass locket, charming but undeniably aged, tarnished from years of existence."
Relative to the first turning point, Jane's situation has changed because she has now encountered Grisly and the mysterious locket, introducing an element of intrigue and potential danger into her life. Her condition can be approximated as a 6 out of 10, as she is still resourceful but now faces unknown challenges and risks associated with the locket.

### 4. Identify the third turning point and state the sentence corresponding to that turning point, and describe how it changed relative to the second turning point.
The third turning point (tp3) is at sentence 14: "As Jane opened the locket in the seclusion of her home, life on the tranquil island began to drastically transform backward."
Relative to the second turning point, Jane's situation has deteriorated significantly because opening the locket has unleashed supernatural forces that disrupt her peaceful life. Her condition can be approximated as a 2 out of 10, as she is now facing intense, unexplained events that threaten her sense of security and well-being.

### 5. Identify the fourth turning point and state the sentence corresponding to that turning point, and describe how it changed relative to the third turning point.
The fourth turning point (tp4) is at sentence 29: "He finally disclosed a chilling legend about the locket; supposedly, it was an enchanted prison for a powerful and ill-tempered witch, captured by a wise shaman centuries before their time."
Relative to the third turning point, Jane's understanding of her situation has changed because she now knows the origin and nature of the locket, but her condition remains dire due to the locket's effects and the townsfolk's changed perception of her. Her condition can be approximated as a 1 out of 10, as she faces not only supernatural threats but also social isolation.

### 6. Identify the fifth turning point and state the sentence corresponding to that turning point, and describe how it changed relative to the fourth turning point.
The fifth turning point (tp5) is at sentence 49: "With her relentless will, she fought and triumphed, successfully trapping the malevolent entity, trapping it back into the confines of the lustrous brass locket."
Relative to the fourth turning point, Jane's situation has improved dramatically because she has confronted and overcome the supernatural threat, restoring a sense of control and normalcy to her life. Her condition can be approximated as a 10 out of 10, as she emerges victorious, empowered, and with a newfound appreciation for her life and connections.

### 7. Approximate the protagonist's condition in the story as a number from 0 to 10 at every turning point and list these numbers in chronological order.
The list of Jane's condition at each turning point is: 5, 6, 2, 1, 10.

### 8. Classify the story arc type based on the protagonist's condition list and explain your reasoning.
The story arc type is "Man in a Hole" because Jane starts in a relatively stable situation (5), encounters an intriguing but risky element (6), falls into a deep crisis (2) that worsens (1), and then rises to a triumphant resolution (10). This pattern follows the "Man in a Hole" arc, where the protagonist faces a dilemma, hits a low point, and then recovers to end up in a better state than at the beginning.

### 9. Determine the story arc type.
Man in a Hole

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each turning point. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Our tale unfolds against the gorgeous canvas of San Francisco in the late 1800s, where Victorian houses speckle the rolling landscape.
2) At its heart, we find our lead character, Patrick Kearney.
3) A physician by profession, Patrick commands respect and admiration amongst his contemporaries.
4) Also forming an integral part of the Kearney homestead is Buster, a dog whose lineage forms an intriguing blend of the noble wolf and the friendly golden retriever.
5) Every day, we watch as Patrick goes about his duties, with Buster his unwavering companion.
6) However, their peaceful cohabitation is suddenly disrupted one afternoon by the arrival of a postman carrying a letter from Carson City, a rustic town located in Nevada.
7) The letter contains alarming details of the dire circumstances his long-lost brother now finds himself in.
8) Panic and worry ensue, and Patrick finds himself torn between his estranged past relationship with his brother and the undeniable bond that familial ties impose.
9) After much inner turmoil, Patrick decides to undertake a rescue mission to save his brother, Joe.
10) He spends a few days gathering essential necessities for his arduous journey.
11) Buster, his faithful companion, remains at Patrick's side throughout.
12) Leaving the familiar coasts of San Francisco behind, they embark on their journey into the unpredictable wilderness.
13) They navigate the hostile wilderness, fraught with extreme weather fluctuations, height changes, and the constant threat of highwaymen.
14) Their journey evolves into more than merely a mission to save someone.
15) It becomes a test of their bond, their ability to endure hardships.
16) As they near the Sierra peak, signs of Patrick's brother surface, amplifying his anticipation.
17) However, they discover the chilling reality of Patrick's brother being held captive by bandits over an assertion regarding an alleged treasure.
18) Patrick and Buster engage in a perilous path filled with danger, but it also provides them with an opportunity to hatch a plan to rescue Joe.
19) What follows is a gripping face-off, where Patrick, aided by a fierce dog, take on a gang of outlaws.
20) The battle ends with Patrick and Buster emerging victorious amidst the defeated outlaws.
21) Following the battle, they discover a hidden trove brimming with gold nuggets, the source of contention among the bandits.
22) Upon setting his brother free, the brothers share a heartfelt reunion.
23) Patrick chooses to leave behind the gold, and they embark on their journey back home to San Francisco.
24) Settling back into city life, the wilderness holds a newfound allure for Patrick.
25) As he sits by his hearth with Buster snoozing at his feet, he realizes that his experiences and relationships built during the journey are worth far more than tangible riches.
26) Days later, Patrick sits overlooking his beloved city of San Francisco.
27) Irrespective of his monetary wealth, he feels a richness in his life that gold cannot equal.
28) His real wealth lies in people he cherishes in his life, the experiences gained, and the wisdom acquired from each challenge.
29) As night falls, the curtain descends on our tale of a man, his loyal dog, and an unforgettable journey that forever redefined their perspective on life.

6) Kevin then suggests that their father "went with mom" but Kaylee does not want to talk about their mother.
7) The toilet in the downstairs bathroom disappears.
8) On their way to the upstairs bathroom, Kaylee sees a doll on a bedroom ceiling and Kevin ends up too frightened to use the toilet, so they decide to place two buckets in the downstairs bathroom.
9) A mysterious voice calls to Kaylee from the darkness and tells her to come upstairs, where she sees their father in a bedroom.
10) He tells her to look under the bed, but she does not see anything.
11) She then sees their mother sitting on the bed.
12) Her mother says that she and their father love Kaylee and Kevin, and instructs her to close her eyes before vanishing.
13) Kaylee looks at the open closet and hears her mother say "there's someone here".
14) From the closet, she hears her mother calling her name as well as moans of pain and bones breaking.
15) She is startled by a hand reaching around a corner and panics.
16) Kaylee runs downstairs, where Kevin helps her push the couch to block off the hallway from which the voice was calling her.
17) When Kevin falls asleep, the voice calls Kaylee again.
18) When Kevin wakes up, he sees that Kaylee is gone and toys and objects are suspended against a wall.
19) The voice beckons Kevin into the basement, where he sees Kaylee, who no longer has eyes or a mouth.
20) The voice tells him it wants to play as some of the toys begin to disappear.
21) A drawer opens in the kitchen, and Kevin complies with the voice's command that he insert a knife into one of his eyes.
22) Kevin calls 9-1-1 and whispers to the operator that he was cut with a knife and feels sick.
23) The operator tells him to stay on the line and that adults are on their way.
24) Kevin says that the doors have disappeared before dropping the phone.
25) The phone turns into a Chatter Telephone toy and the voice claims responsibility for this, telling Kevin that it can "do anything".
26) It says that Kaylee disobeyed it and demanded to see her parents, so it took away her mouth.
27) It tells Kevin to come upstairs.
28) Holding a flashlight, Kevin finds himself on the ceiling.
29) He walks into a bedroom which becomes a void, and a dollhouse is shown sitting on a pile of toys in a seemingly infinite hallway as onscreen text reads "572 days".
30) A woman is seen sitting on the bed and her head slowly fades away, followed by the rest of her body.
31) Photos are shown of people, except their faces are either missing or distorted.
32) Kevin cries out as blood splatters onto the floor, then disappears and splatters repeatedly.
33) He asks if he can watch something happy, followed by an apparition of a door.
34) In the dark, an unidentifiable face appears over him in his bed, telling him to go to sleep.
35) Kevin asks for the face's name twice, but it does not respond.

Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Hollywood actor Nicolas "Nick" Cage is struggling with his career after being passed over for several major film roles and is constantly pestered and tormented by "Nicky", who appears to him as his younger (and more successful) self.
2) His relationship with his ex-wife Olivia and daughter Addy is also marred by years of emotional neglect.
3) Losing a key film role and following an embarrassing event at Addy's birthday party, Nick plans to retire from acting.
4) He decides to accept a vague offer of $1 million from his agent Richard Fink that involves going to Majorca to meet billionaire playboy Javi Gutierrez and to be the guest of honor at his birthday.
5) Upon meeting Javi, Nick is initially annoyed by his neediness and insistence that they create an improvisational movie based on a script he wrote, but is soon inspired by Javi's determination, and the two of them quickly bond over their surprisingly shared love of films such as The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari and Paddington 2 (the latter of which Nick watches for the first time with Javi).
6) Soon after, Nick is confronted by CIA agents Vivian and Martin.
7) They suspect that Javi, who they claim made his fortune through arms dealing, is behind the kidnapping of Maria, the daughter of a Catalan anti-crime politician, with the hope that he will drop out of an upcoming election.
8) Nick insists that his acting instincts would've detected if Javi was a criminal, but he eventually decides to help the CIA with the mission.
9) After successfully rigging the cameras in Javi's compound, Nick attends a party where he announces his collaboration with Javi on a new movie, as an excuse to stay on the compound long enough to find Maria.
10) After a misadventure involving LSD, Nick and Javi decide that their movie should be about their relationship.
11) Nick later discovers that Javi keeps a shrine room dedicated to all of his movies, including a wax figure of his character Castor Troy from the film Face/Off, complete with identical golden pistols.
12) Vivian suggests that Nick includes a kidnapping in their script, to get Javi's reaction to it.
13) Nick explains his new idea to Javi, who believes that Nick is distracted by his family issues.
14) Vivian tells Nick to flee, or possibly kill Javi, as Javi has discovered their plot.
15) But Javi reveals he's brought Nick's family to his villa.
16) Nick tries to make amends with them, but they reject his appeal and accuse him of prioritizing his film career over his family.
17) Javi privately goes to meet with his cousin Lucas, who is revealed to be the true arms dealer and the one who kidnapped Maria.
18) Lucas warns him that Nick is working with the CIA and pressures him to kill Nick, or else Lucas will kill Javi.
19) Nick and Javi face off, but neither can bring himself to kill the other.
20) Lucas sends his men after both of them, and they race back to the house to discover that Addy has been kidnapped.
21) Nick takes Javi, Olivia and Javi's assistant Gabriela to the CIA safe house, only for the house to have been compromised; Martin has been killed, while Vivian sacrifices herself to kill Lucas's men before they can ambush the group.
22) With Javi's help, Nick and Olivia pose as a reclusive criminal couple to get close to Lucas.
23) He figures out their plan, but they still manage to escape with Addy and Maria.
24) Nick, Addy, Olivia and Maria race to the American embassy while Javi and Gabriela stay behind to delay Lucas's pursuit.
25) Upon arrival, Lucas holds Nick at gunpoint, but Addy tosses him a knife which Nick uses to kill him—transitioning into the movie that Nick and Javi completed, presumably based on their adventure.
26) Nick is applauded for his new film and congratulates Javi before going home with his family to watch Paddington 2, now with a better relationship.

The list of Nick's conditions at each turning point in chronological order is: 2, 4, 7, 5, 10.

### 8. Classify the story arc type based on the protagonist's condition list and explain your reasoning.
The story arc type can be classified based on the pattern of the protagonist's condition throughout the story. Given the list 2, 4, 7, 5, 10, we observe that Nick starts in a disadvantaged situation (2), improves his condition as the story progresses (4, 7), faces a setback (5), and ultimately ends in a much better situation than where he started (10). This pattern matches the "Man in a Hole" story arc, where the protagonist falls into a dilemma, finds a way out, and ends better than at the beginning.

### 9. Determine the story arc type
Man in a Hole
